title: mokacoding
description: A blog about testing, iOS development, productivity, and blabber about software in general.

items.title: WWDC21: What's New in Testing
items.content_html: A roundup of the testing-related new features announced at WWDC 2021. Including Xcode Cloud, how to test code using async/await, the new XCTExpectFailure and addTearDownBlock APIs, and the new Test Repetition configuration in Test Plans.
items.summary: A roundup of the testing-related new features announced at WWDC 2021. Including Xcode Cloud, how to test code using async/await, the new XCTExpectFailure and addTearDownBlock APIs, and the new Test Repetition configuration in Test Plans.

items.title: How to test Swift async/await code with XCTest
items.content_html: Swift 5.5 and Xcode 13 introduce the async/await pattern for concurrent code. This tutorial post shows how to write unit tests for asynchronous code in Swift using the XCTest framework.
items.summary: Swift 5.5 and Xcode 13 introduce the async/await pattern for concurrent code. This tutorial post shows how to write unit tests for asynchronous code in Swift using the XCTest framework.

items.title: How to write better tests for Swift date comparisons
items.content_html: Testing Swift date comparison code with XCTest can result in indeterministic tests because of the passage of time. To make tests robust and deterministic, decouple them from the system clock by injecting the reference date.
items.summary: Testing Swift date comparison code with XCTest can result in indeterministic tests because of the passage of time. To make tests robust and deterministic, decouple them from the system clock by injecting the reference date.

items.title: On the benefits of distributed work
items.content_html: Working from home doesn't have to be lonely. Going from remote to distributed can bring massive benefits to employees satisfaction and company productivity.
items.summary: Working from home doesn't have to be lonely. Going from remote to distributed can bring massive benefits to employees satisfaction and company productivity.

items.title: How to manage complex inputs in your Swift tests with Scenario Builders
items.content_html: When writing unit tests in Swift for complex objects, you may need to write a lot of setup boilerplate code in the arrange phase. Scenario Builders are a pattern that extracts and encapsulated all that logic in a single component with an English-like API. This tutorial shows how to build a Scenario Builder in Swift and looks at its pros and cons.
items.summary: When writing unit tests in Swift for complex objects, you may need to write a lot of setup boilerplate code in the arrange phase. Scenario Builders are a pattern that extracts and encapsulated all that logic in a single component with an English-like API. This tutorial shows how to build a Scenario Builder in Swift and looks at its pros and cons.

items.title: A World Without Slack
items.content_html: How to establish a workflow that minimizes unscheduled, unstructured communication and maximizes focus and productivity.
items.summary: How to establish a workflow that minimizes unscheduled, unstructured communication and maximizes focus and productivity.

items.title: A distributed asynchronous release process
items.content_html: My latest post on mobile.blog explores two simple conventions Automattic uses to remove the need for synchronous meetings in their app release process.
items.summary: My latest post on mobile.blog explores two simple conventions Automattic uses to remove the need for synchronous meetings in their app release process.

items.title: Working Backwards
items.content_html: How working your way backwards from your desired outcome can make you more productive, focused, and motivated.
items.summary: How working your way backwards from your desired outcome can make you more productive, focused, and motivated.

items.title: How waiting in line can improve your focus
items.content_html: Embrace boredom to train your brain to sustain focus when working on demanding tasks
items.summary: Embrace boredom to train your brain to sustain focus when working on demanding tasks

items.title: Unit Testing Combine Publisher Cheatsheet
items.content_html: Snippets to test the behavior of Combine Publishers in XCTest ready to copy and paste into Xcode

items.title: Boring Iterations. Interesting Steps.
items.content_html: Camille Fournier encourages us to "Make Boring Plans" and move in small iterations.
items.summary: Camille Fournier encourages us to "Make Boring Plans" and move in small iterations.

items.title: How to migrate from SwiftUI to UIKit App Delegate Life Cycle in Xcode
items.content_html: This free tutorial shows how to migrate an existing app with SwiftUI life cycle to use UIKit App Delegate instead
items.summary: This free tutorial shows how to migrate an existing app with SwiftUI life cycle to use UIKit App Delegate instead

items.title: How to stick with your New Year resolutions
items.content_html: The start of a new year is a great time to work on self-improvement, but unless you take the right steps, your New Year resolutions might not stick.
items.summary: The start of a new year is a great time to work on self-improvement, but unless you take the right steps, your New Year resolutions might not stick.

items.title: How to set default values in Swift compiler-generated initializers
items.content_html: You can get the Swift compiler to generate an initializer with default values for your structs, if you're willing to put up with a bit of mutability.
items.summary: You can get the Swift compiler to generate an initializer with default values for your structs, if you're willing to put up with a bit of mutability.

items.title: How to improve your Test-Driven Development workflow by asking "Do I need this yet?"
items.content_html: The "You Don't Need It Yet" technique to ship software on a schedule results in fast real-world feeback. The same mindset can be applied with Test-Driven Development to move between the Red, Green, and Refactor stages faster.
items.summary: The "You Don't Need It Yet" technique to ship software on a schedule results in fast real-world feeback. The same mindset can be applied with Test-Driven Development to move between the Red, Green, and Refactor stages faster.

items.title: Write better Swift unit tests with custom XCTest assertions
items.content_html: The XCTest Swift testing framework has a limited offer of assertions. There's only so much you can do with XCTAssertTrue and XCTAssertEqual. This XCTest tutorial shows how to create custom assertions to make your unit tests and UI tests shorter and clearer.
items.summary: The XCTest Swift testing framework has a limited offer of assertions. There's only so much you can do with XCTAssertTrue and XCTAssertEqual. This XCTest tutorial shows how to create custom assertions to make your unit tests and UI tests shorter and clearer.

items.title: How to write unit test assertions for Swift Result values
items.content_html: Result is one of the most useful types in the Swift language. Learn how to write better unit tests using Result in this XCTest tutorial.
items.summary: Result is one of the most useful types in the Swift language. Learn how to write better unit tests using Result in this XCTest tutorial.

items.title: When experiments go wrong
items.content_html: Scientist can learn a lot from failed experiments. To do so, they must be methodical and collect all sorts of information. Softwar developers can learn a lot from failures, too. What are the practicies that can make learning easier?
items.summary: Scientist can learn a lot from failed experiments. To do so, they must be methodical and collect all sorts of information. Softwar developers can learn a lot from failures, too. What are the practicies that can make learning easier?

items.title: How to merge pull requests with a commit that improves your Git history
items.content_html: When merging a pull request on GitHub, it helps to replace the default merge commit title with the PR title or an equally descriptive one. This will make your Git history more informative, and developers will understand the changes in the Git log faster.
items.summary: When merging a pull request on GitHub, it helps to replace the default merge commit title with the PR title or an equally descriptive one. This will make your Git history more informative, and developers will understand the changes in the Git log faster.

items.title: How to bypass the SwiftUI App when running unit tests
items.content_html: How to make the unit tests of your SwiftUI app safer and faster by preventing them from running the program startup flow. This will avoid all of the launch operations like network requests or reads from the local storage that would affect the global state.
items.summary: How to make the unit tests of your SwiftUI app safer and faster by preventing them from running the program startup flow. This will avoid all of the launch operations like network requests or reads from the local storage that would affect the global state.

items.title: What can a pipe wrench teach us about software engineering?

items.content_html: YDNIY is a purposeful restraint of what you decide to build in the interest of delivering value to the users as soon as possible and consistently.
items.summary: YDNIY is a purposeful restraint of what you decide to build in the interest of delivering value to the users as soon as possible and consistently.

items.title: How to become drastically faster at using the terminal

items.title: How to split decision and action logic with the Swift type system
items.content_html: There is a subtle way to overload software components, by making them both take decision and act on them. We can simplify these bloated components by separating the responsibility of taking decisions from the one action on them. This will result in leaner and easier to maintain software, and is made simple by the Swift type system.
items.summary: There is a subtle way to overload software components, by making them both take decision and act on them. We can simplify these bloated components by separating the responsibility of taking decisions from the one action on them. This will result in leaner and easier to maintain software, and is made simple by the Swift type system.

items.title: Red, green, and don't forget refactor

items.title: Language Agnostic Automation Setup
items.content_html: Every project can benefit from having a set of scripts to automate tasks such as running tests or distributing to testers. This will make it easier for new team members to get started, and allow you to change the setup without having to change the way the scripts are invoked.

items.title: Getting Started With OHHTTPStubs
items.content_html: Good unit tests are fast and deterministic. Testing code that hits the network could undermine this goal, but using OHHTTPStubs we can take back control of our tests. This post explores the advantages of stubbing the network, and provide a guide on how to do it with OHHTTPStubs.
items.summary: Good unit tests are fast and deterministic. Testing code that hits the network could undermine this goal, but using OHHTTPStubs we can take back control of our tests. This post explores the advantages of stubbing the network, and provide a guide on how to do it with OHHTTPStubs.

items.title: Why hitting the network is bad for your test, and what to do about it
items.content_html: In this post we are going to look at why hitting the network from your unit tests is a bad thing, and introduce some way to solve the problem.
items.summary: In this post we are going to look at why hitting the network from your unit tests is a bad thing, and introduce some way to solve the problem.

items.title: Ruby for iOS Developers - Managing Ruby Tools with Bundler
items.content_html: Between CocoaPods and Fastlane, Ruby is an important part of the iOS developer toolchain. How can we reliably control the versions of the tools our project's automation is using in Ruby? Bundler is a simple way to specify Ruby dependencies and automate their setup.
items.summary: Between CocoaPods and Fastlane, Ruby is an important part of the iOS developer toolchain. How can we reliably control the versions of the tools our project's automation is using in Ruby? Bundler is a simple way to specify Ruby dependencies and automate their setup.

items.title: Ruby for iOS Developers - Managing Ruby Versions
items.content_html: Between CocoaPods and Fastlane, Ruby is an important part of the iOS developer toolchain. Managing versions and gems can be a challenge for developers outside of the Ruby community, but it doesn't have to be. In this two parts post we will see how to simply and reliably handle our Rubies.
items.summary: Between CocoaPods and Fastlane, Ruby is an important part of the iOS developer toolchain. Managing versions and gems can be a challenge for developers outside of the Ruby community, but it doesn't have to be. In this two parts post we will see how to simply and reliably handle our Rubies.

items.title: How To Fix Fabric Crashing On Startup When Installed Via CocoaPods
items.content_html: If you are experiencing crashes with a version of Fabric and Crashlytics installed via CocoaPods chances are you are missing required information in the Info.plist. This post shows how to solve this issue.
items.summary: If you are experiencing crashes with a version of Fabric and Crashlytics installed via CocoaPods chances are you are missing required information in the Info.plist. This post shows how to solve this issue.

items.title: When to use map, flatMap, or for loops in Swift

items.title: Swift Optionals, Functional Programming, and You
items.content_html: This is the post version of a talk I've been given in the past months. In this post we will demystify functional programming terms like monad and functor, and see how those concepts can be brought back to the every day Swift development, in particular how they can help to deal with optionals in a leaner way.
items.summary: This is the post version of a talk I've been given in the past months. In this post we will demystify functional programming terms like monad and functor, and see how those concepts can be brought back to the every day Swift development, in particular how they can help to deal with optionals in a leaner way.

items.title: An even lighter way to use Carthage
items.content_html: Among the options Carthage, an iOS and OS X dependency manager, provides there is the --no-build one. Using this we can integrate dependencies in the form of Xcode projects rather than frameworks, keeping the repository slimmer and the CI time low. This approach is lighter than than the usual way to work with Carthage, but comes with some disadvantages too.
items.summary: Among the options Carthage, an iOS and OS X dependency manager, provides there is the --no-build one. Using this we can integrate dependencies in the form of Xcode projects rather than frameworks, keeping the repository slimmer and the CI time low. This approach is lighter than than the usual way to work with Carthage, but comes with some disadvantages too.

items.title: How to install Xcode Command Line Tools without GUI or Xcode
items.content_html: Here's a little script that will allow you to install the Xcode Command Line Tools without having to install Xcode, nor having a logged GUI. This can come pretty handy in automated scripts or when provisioning virtual machines.
items.summary: Here's a little script that will allow you to install the Xcode Command Line Tools without having to install Xcode, nor having a logged GUI. This can come pretty handy in automated scripts or when provisioning virtual machines.

items.title: /dev/world/2015 notes of a testing fanboy
items.content_html: I attended /dev/world/2015 in Melbourne this week. It has been a great conference, full of very friendly and smart people. Being a test and automation fanboy I attended as many talks related to that topic as I could. These are my notes.

items.title: Enhancing XCTest test cases with Nimble matchers
items.content_html: Nimble is a matchers framework built for Swift that provides powerful and versatile expectations. Writing test within the standard XCTest harness but using Nimble assertions is easier and productive, and a good combination of tools to introduce testing and TDD to colleagues and teams in a frictionless way.
items.summary: Nimble is a matchers framework built for Swift that provides powerful and versatile expectations. Writing test within the standard XCTest harness but using Nimble assertions is easier and productive, and a good combination of tools to introduce testing and TDD to colleagues and teams in a frictionless way.

items.title: Explicit Dependencies for Code with No Surprises
items.content_html: Sometimes the idea we get when reading a class interface is different from what is actually going on inside its implementation, for example there could be several hidden dependencies. Making a class dependency explicit in its interface is a useful technique to make the code simpler to understand, and easier to test.
items.summary: Sometimes the idea we get when reading a class interface is different from what is actually going on inside its implementation, for example there could be several hidden dependencies. Making a class dependency explicit in its interface is a useful technique to make the code simpler to understand, and easier to test.

items.title: Keep Your Bench Clean
items.content_html: Like good chefs keep their benches clean to make delicious dishes all day long in the restaurants' kitchens, so good developer keep their codebase clean. It all comes down to little habits, the result of which when summed up together is a tidy, clean and easy to maintain software.
items.summary: Like good chefs keep their benches clean to make delicious dishes all day long in the restaurants' kitchens, so good developer keep their codebase clean. It all comes down to little habits, the result of which when summed up together is a tidy, clean and easy to maintain software.

items.title: How to test UI changes in Xcode 7
items.content_html: One of the characteristic of the UI is that it changes, and there are scenarios in which writing UI tests to assure that the change has happened correctly can be very valuable for the reliability of our apps. Writing such a test is a bit harder than normal, let's see how to do it.

items.title: MailChimp automated workflow for mokacoding weekly
items.content_html: At mokacoding we're big on automation, and we eat our own dog's food! The workflow to write and send new issues of our newsletter, mokacoding weekly, is (partially) automated thanks to some simple Ruby scripting and Mac command line utilities.
items.summary: At mokacoding we're big on automation, and we eat our own dog's food! The workflow to write and send new issues of our newsletter, mokacoding weekly, is (partially) automated thanks to some simple Ruby scripting and Mac command line utilities.

items.title: Automation with pre-commit hooks
items.content_html: Git provides a mechanism to run one or more scripts before a commit is actually added to the history called pre-commit hook. We can use this hook to run scripts that validate or sanitise the changes to be committed automatically, saving time and brain power, and assuring the quality of the codbase and git log.
items.summary: Git provides a mechanism to run one or more scripts before a commit is actually added to the history called pre-commit hook. We can use this hook to run scripts that validate or sanitise the changes to be committed automatically, saving time and brain power, and assuring the quality of the codbase and git log.

items.title: xUnique: a tool to avoid Xcode project merge conflicts
items.content_html: How many times when working on a Mac OSX or iOS app with a team have you had a merge conflict on the project.pbxproj file? I guess more than a few, a lot more than a few. Lucky for you there is an handy tool called xUnique that will make the chances of this happening way smaller.
items.summary: How many times when working on a Mac OSX or iOS app with a team have you had a merge conflict on the project.pbxproj file? I guess more than a few, a lot more than a few. Lucky for you there is an handy tool called xUnique that will make the chances of this happening way smaller.

items.title: Writing an Expecta custom matcher
items.content_html: Not only Expecta is a simple to use library that allows us to write highly readable code, but it can also be extended by the users with custom matchers. Let's see how to write a custom matcher to gain readability and reuse code in our test suites.
items.summary: Not only Expecta is a simple to use library that allows us to write highly readable code, but it can also be extended by the users with custom matchers. Let's see how to write a custom matcher to gain readability and reuse code in our test suites.

items.title: Expecta, a matcher library that speaks English
items.content_html: A test that express is intent clearly is arguably twice as effective as one that doesn't. Writing test in an xSpec style is a good first step to express behaviour clearly, and when matched with a matcher library such as Expecta the results are test that are easy to read and reason about
items.summary: A test that express is intent clearly is arguably twice as effective as one that doesn't. Writing test in an xSpec style is a good first step to express behaviour clearly, and when matched with a matcher library such as Expecta the results are test that are easy to read and reason about

items.title: Specta global before and after each hooks (Updated)
items.content_html: An interesting and powerful, yet not at all documented feature of Spetca are global beforeEach and afterEach hooks. In this post we'll see how to configure them, and how to blacklist classes from running them. Updated for version 0.5
items.summary: An interesting and powerful, yet not at all documented feature of Spetca are global beforeEach and afterEach hooks. In this post we'll see how to configure them, and how to blacklist classes from running them. Updated for version 0.5

items.title: Job stories acceptance tests using KIF and Specta
items.content_html: When writing tests it's very important do be declarative, aiming to have tests that explain how a class is supposed to behave as good as its documentation would do. When talking about acceptance tests we can achieve this kind of clarity by having a 1:1 relationship between the tests and the acceptance criteria for the application. A very effective way to express acceptance criteria is through _job stories_. In this post we'll see how to write acceptance tests that map job stories for our iOS apps, using KIF and Specta.
items.summary: When writing tests it's very important do be declarative, aiming to have tests that explain how a class is supposed to behave as good as its documentation would do. When talking about acceptance tests we can achieve this kind of clarity by having a 1:1 relationship between the tests and the acceptance criteria for the application. A very effective way to express acceptance criteria is through _job stories_. In this post we'll see how to write acceptance tests that map job stories for our iOS apps, using KIF and Specta.

items.title: Better tests with Specta
items.content_html: Writing unit tests for our iOS and OS X projects not only is important, but should be always part of the development cycle. As such the way we write the tests is as important, and having the option to write tests that easily explain their purpose can drastically increase the quality of the suite. Specta and Expecta are two libraries that provide a different way to writing tests than XCTest, let's see what we can gain by using such approach.
items.summary: Writing unit tests for our iOS and OS X projects not only is important, but should be always part of the development cycle. As such the way we write the tests is as important, and having the option to write tests that easily explain their purpose can drastically increase the quality of the suite. Specta and Expecta are two libraries that provide a different way to writing tests than XCTest, let's see what we can gain by using such approach.
